case_name: Bhanwar Singh and another v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 9, 1967 of the Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 254 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 9, 1967 of the Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 254 of 1966.

facts.text: Two appellants convicted by Additional Sessions Judge No. 1, Jaipur City for offences under ss. 120B, 420, 420/511, 467/471 IPC, confirmed by Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants, in this appeal, by special leave, challenge their conviction, by the Additional Sessions Judge, No. 1, Jaipur City, for offences under ss. 120B, 420, 420 read with 511, and 467 read with 471, I.P.C., as confirmed by the High Court of Rajasthan, at Jodhpur.

facts.text: Bhanwar Singh convicted for offence under S. 380 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Bhanwar Singh has also been convicted, for an offence under S. 380, I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellants and two others tried by Sessions Judge; two others acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants, along with two others, who have since been acquitted, were tried by the learned Sessions Judge, for various offences, as indicated below.

facts.text: Four accused charged with common criminal conspiracy under S. 120B IPC to commit theft, cheating, forgery on postal orders and cheques.

anchor.surface_text: There was a common charge of criminal conspiracy, under S. 120B, IPC, to do, or cause to be done, illegal acts, viz., offences of theft, cheating, forgeries, etc., against all the four accused. Under this head, the allegation was that the four accused agreed, among themselves, to commit theft and pilferage, of Indian and British postal orders and bank cheques, belonging to different persons, which were in transmission, by post

facts.text: Accused agreed to erase original payees and post offices from pilfered postal orders/cheques, forge names of fictitious persons or accused, and different post offices.

anchor.surface_text: ...and that, after such pilfering, the names of the original payees and the names of the paying post offices were erased and forgery was committed by writing the names of fictitious persons, or the names of some of the accused, and of different post offices.

facts.text: Accused agreed to present pilfered and forged postal orders/cheques for encashment at post offices and banks in Ajmer and Jaipur through appellants and Yasoda Devi.

anchor.surface_text: ...The further allegation was that the accused agreed to use, as genuine, all such pilfered and forged postal orders and cheques, which the accused knew, or had reasons to believe, were forged documents. There was also an allegation that all the accused had also agreed to present, such pilfered and forged postal orders and cheques, for encashment at the post offices and banks at Ajmer and Jaipur, through the two appellants and Yasoda Devi, 4th accused, pretending to be either the original payees or the substituted payees.

facts.text: Bhanwar Singh charged with theft of postal orders/cheques during October 1956 and December 1957, forgery by inserting own name, cheating postal authorities at Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Bhanwar Singh was also further charged that, in pursuance of the conspiracy, during October 1956 and December 1957, he committed theft of various postal orders and cheques, belonging to various persons and that he also forged certain postal orders, which were valuable securities, by removing the names of the original payees and inserting his own name and that he thereby cheated the postal authorities at Jaipur, by dishonestly inducing them to deliver certain amounts against such postal orders, which were really payable to a third party, and thereby he committed offences of theft, forgery and cheating, under ss. 380, 467 and 420, I.P.C.

facts.text: Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand were constables in C.I.D., Ajmer Zone during 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand were constables in the C.I.D., Ajmer Zone, during 1956-57.

facts.text: Constables pilfered Indian and British postal orders and cheques while censoring postal mail, erased original payees and post offices/banks, inserted own or fictitious names, encashed at post offices and banks.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of their duties of censoring postal mail, these two constables, after having opened the mail, for the purpose of censoring, pilfered certain Indian postal orders and British postal orders and cheques and, after erasing the names of the original payees, as also the names of the post offices or banks, where payment was to be made, inserted their own names or some fictitious names and got the postal orders or cheques encashed at different post offices and banks.

facts.text: Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand conspired with Kishanlal and Yashoda Devi to encash the pilfered items.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand had entered into a conspiracy, with Kishanlal and Yashoda Devi, whose services were utilised for getting the moneys from the Banks.

facts.text: Matter came to light when payees did not receive cheques/postal orders and lodged complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The matter came to light when the payees did not receive the cheques or the postal orders intended for them and lodged complaints with the post offices and banks.

facts.text: Accused denied the charges.

anchor.surface_text: The accused denied the charges levelled against them.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held conspiracy charge established against all four accused.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge came to the conclusion that the charge of criminal conspiracy was established, against all the four accused

facts.text: First appellant (Bhanwar Singh) convicted under ss. 380, 467/471, 420/511 r/w 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant was found to be the main accused and he was convicted under ss. 380, 467/471, 420/511 read with S. 120B P.C.

facts.text: Second appellant (Kishanlal) and Yashoda Devi convicted under ss. 467, 471, 420 r/w 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The second appellant and Yashoda Devi were convicted under ss. 467, 471 and 420 read with S. 120B IPC.

facts.text: Kapoorchand convicted under ss. 380, 467 r/w 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Kapoorchand was however convicted only for offences under ss. 380 and 467 read with 120-B, IPC.

facts.text: All four accused appealed to Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: All the four accused challenged their conviction for these offences and the sentence passed against them, before the High Court of Rajasthan.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Yashoda Devi due to insufficient evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, acquitted Yashoda Devi, holding that the prosecution evidence did not establish her guilt, beyond reasonable doubt.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Kapoorchand holding trial void for lack of sanction under S. 196A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also acquitted Kapoorchand holding that the trial against him was void, because the necessary sanction had not been obtained, under S. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: No sanction under S. 196A CrPC obtained for offences under ss. 467/471 r/w 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that inasmuch as the accused were prosecuted for non-cognizable offences under ss. 467/471 read with S. 120B, IPC., the trial was illegal and void, inasmuch as the necessary sanction, under S. 196A of the Code had not been obtained.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no sanction necessary as main object of conspiracy was cheating under S. 420 IPC, forgery incidental.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the various High Courts... is that no sanction is necessary, under s. 196A (2) Cr.P.C., when the object of the conspiracy is to commit the offence of cheating (420 IPC), but, forgery of documents (467 IPC) and similar non-cognizable offences are also committed, as merely steps taken... for the purpose of effecting the main object of the conspiracy.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejects appellants' contentions and upholds convictions.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what is stated above, the first contention of the learned counsel for the appellants, has to be rejected. So far as the second contention is concerned... Both the learned Sessions Judge, as well as the High Court, have very elaborately gone into the evidence... and there is no justification for any interference, by this Court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 9, 1967 of the Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 254 of 1966.

The two appellants, in this appeal, by special leave, challenge their conviction, by the Additional Sessions Judge, No. 1, Jaipur City, for offences under ss. 120B, 420, 420 read with 511, and 467 read with 471, I.P.C., as confirmed by the High Court of Rajasthan, at Jodhpur.

concepts.interpretation: No sanction required under sub-s.(2) when conspiracy object is cognizable offence like cheating u/s 420 IPC, even if non-cognizable like forgery u/s 467 are means to achieve it.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Bhanwar Singh was also further charged that, in pursuance of the conspiracy, during October 1956 and December 1957, he committed theft of various postal orders and cheques, belonging to various persons and that he also forged certain postal orders, which were valuable securities, by removing the names of the original payees and inserting his own name and that he thereby cheated the postal authorities at Jaipur, by dishonestly inducing them to deliver certain amounts against such postal orders, which were really payable to a third party, and thereby he committed offences of theft, forgery and cheating, under ss. 380, 467 and 420, I.P.C.
Kapoorchand was also charged under ss. 380 and 467 I.P.C., and Yasoda Devi, under ss. 467, 471, 420 and 419 I.P.C.

Counsel urged that inasmuch as the accused were prosecuted for non-cognizable offences under ss. 467/471 read with S. 120B, IPC., the trial was illegal and void, inasmuch as the necessary sanction, under S. 196A of the Code had not been obtained.

concepts.interpretation: Offences u/ss 467, 471 IPC are non-cognizable requiring sanction u/s 196A CrPC unless part of conspiracy with cognizable main object.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object. Even if the object of the conspiracy, viz., of cheating, is sought to be attained by resort to non-cognizable offences, as in the case before us, sanction under s. 196A of the Code is not necessary.

concepts.interpretation: Object of conspiracy determined by reading charges; if to commit cognizable offence like cheating, non-cognizable means like forgery do not require sanction.

issues.text: Was the trial illegal and void because the necessary sanction under S. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure had not been obtained in respect of the charge under ss. 467 and 471 read with S. 120B IPC?

anchor.surface_text: Two contentions were raised by the accused  i  that the trial held by the Sessions Judge was illegal and void, inasmuch as the prosecution had been conducted, without obtaining the necessary sanction, under S. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1 in respect of the charge under ss. 467 and 471 read with S. 120B IPC

issues.text: Did the evidence adduced by the prosecution establish the guilt of the accused?

anchor.surface_text: ii  that the evidence adduced by the prosecution, did not establish the guilt of the accused. Both these contentions have been negatived by the High Court, so far as the appellants herein are concerned.

issues.text: Whether sanction under s. 196A of the Code was necessary when there was a trial for offences under s. 120B read with ss. 467/471 and 420 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: The question is, whether sanction was necessary in the case before us, when there was a trial for offences under s. 467/471 and 420 IPC, read with S. 120B. In the instant case, it is admitted that nosanction was ob-

issues.text: What was the object of the conspiracy and were the forgeries the object or merely means to achieve cheating?

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object. Even if the object of the conspiracy, viz., of cheating, is sought to be attained by resort to non-cognizable offences,

issues.answer: Cheating was the object; forgery was means

arguments.court_reasoning: Object of conspiracy determined from charges was to commit cheating (cognizable); non-cognizable forgeries incidental

arguments.claim: Mere fact of trial for cognizable offence of cheating under S.420 IPC does not validate the trial for non-cognizable offences without sanction; joint trial illegal

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel further urged that the mere fact that the accused were also tried for the offence of cheating, under S. 420 IPC, which is cognizable and for which punishment by way of imprisonment extending to 7 years could be imposed, and for which no sanction was necessary, would not make the trial valid. Under such circumstances, the joint trial for cognizable and non-cognizable offences was illegal and void.

arguments.claim: Main object of conspiracy was to cheat banks and post offices under S.420 IPC; forgeries on cheques/postal orders incidental to achieve main object; no sanction under S.196A needed

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Khanna, learned counsel for the State, met this contention, on behalf of the appellant, by pointing out that the main object of the conspiracy was to cheat the banks and the post offices, by obtaining money from them the forgeries committed by the accused on the cheques and postal orders were only incidental to achieve the main object of the conspiracy, viz., to commit the offence under S. 420 IPC.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: post offices, referred to in the charges, which is an offence under S. 420, read with s. 120B, IPC, for which numbersanction is necessary. No doubt t

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with view of various High Courts; object vs means distinction; charges show cheating as object

arguments.claim: As per decisions of Andhra Pradesh HC (Subbaiah In re), Gujarat HC (Jadeda Meramanji), Calcutta HC (Nibaran Chandra), sanction necessary for conspiracy to non-cognizable offences making trial void

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, reliance has been placed on three decisions... Subbaiah, In re 2 , of the Andhra Pradesh High Court Jadeda Meramanji v. State of Gujarat 3 , of the Gujarat High Court and Nibaran Chandra v. Emperor 4 , of the Calcutta High Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and similar number- companynizable offences are also companymitted, as merely steps taken, by one or other of the accused, for the purpose of effectin

arguments.court_reasoning: Calcutta case object was non-cog s.384; AP/Guj cases did not address scenario where prosecution case is cheating as object and non-cog as means

arguments.claim: High Court acquittal of Kapoorchand due to lack of sanction under S.196A applies similarly here, vitiating trial

anchor.surface_text: Before closing the discussion, on this point, it is necessary to refer to the reliance placed, by the counsel for the appellants, on the acquittal, by the High Court, of Kapoorchand, on the ground that the trial was void, because the necessary sanction had not been obtained, under S. 196A, of the Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: g also. It is number necessary to pursuematter further, because, it Will be seen from the judgment of the trial Court that the said accused was also p

arguments.court_reasoning: Kapoorchand also tried under s.120B r/w s.420; not necessary to pursue further as first contention rejected on merits

arguments.claim: No sanction under s.196A(2) CrPC required when object of conspiracy is cheating (s.420 IPC cognizable) but non-cognizable forgery (s.467 IPC) committed as steps/means to effect main object

anchor.surface_text: The view of the various High Courts... is that no sanction is necessary, under s. 196A (2) Cr.P.C., when the object of the conspiracy is to commit the offence of cheating (420 IPC), but, forgery of documents (467 IPC) and similar non-cognizable offences are also committed, as merely steps taken...

arguments.claim: Distinction between object of conspiracy (cheating) and means (non-cognizable offences like forgery); sanction not necessary even if non-cog offences resorted to achieve object

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object. Even if the object of the conspiracy, viz., of cheating, is sought to be attained by resort to non-cognizable offences,

arguments.claim: Object of conspiracy determined by reading charges themselves, not just sections; here object was cheating post offices/banks under s.420 r/w 120B; forgery/use only means

anchor.surface_text: The object of the conspiracy has to be determined, not only by reference to the sections of the penal enactment, referred to in the charge, but on a reading of the charges themselves. On a perusal of the charges, framed against the appellants, we are satisfied that the only object of the conspiracy was to cheat the banks or the post offices

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge and High Court correctly appreciated evidence establishing guilt of appellants; no error warranting interference

anchor.surface_text: In view of what is stated above, the first contention of the learned counsel for the appellants, has to be rejected. So far as the second contention is concerned... Both the learned Sessions Judge, as well as the High Court, have very elaborately gone into the evidence... and there is no justification for any interference, by this Court.

holdings.text: No sanction is necessary under s. 196A(2) Cr.P.C. when the object of the conspiracy is to commit the offence of cheating (s.420 IPC), but forgery of documents (s.467 IPC) and similar non-cognizable offences are committed as merely steps taken for effecting the main object of the conspiracy.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the various High Courts... is that no sanction is necessary, under s. 196A (2) Cr.P.C., when the object of the conspiracy is to commit the offence of cheating (420 IPC), but, forgery of documents (467 IPC) and similar non-cognizable offences are also committed, as merely steps taken...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with view of various High Courts distinguishing object (cheating, cognizable) from incidental means (forgery, non-cognizable); cites supporting precedents; applies to conspiracy charges.

holdings.text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object; even if object of cheating is attained by non-cognizable offences like forgery, no sanction under s.196A CrPC is necessary.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object. Even if the object of the conspiracy, viz., of cheating, is sought to be attained by resort to non-cognizable offences,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emphasizes doctrinal distinction between conspiracy object and means; applies statutory interpretation of s.196A to facts where non-cognizable acts are incidental.

holdings.text: The object of the conspiracy has to be determined not only by reference to the sections but on a reading of the charges themselves; here, the only object was to cheat banks/post offices under s.420 r/w s.120B IPC, forgery/use of forged documents were means.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the conspiracy has to be determined, not only by reference to the sections of the penal enactment, referred to in the charge, but on a reading of the charges themselves. On a perusal of the charges, framed against the appellants, we are satisfied that the only object of the conspiracy was to cheat the banks or the post offices

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reads charges as whole to identify object as cheating; forgery incidental; textual analysis of indictment.

holdings.text: The trial of the accused for offences under s.120B r/w ss.467/471 and 420 IPC without sanction under s.196A(2) CrPC is neither illegal nor void.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the trial of these accused, for offences under ss. 120B read with S. 467/ 471 and 420 IPC., and other allied offences, cannot be held to be illegal, on the ground that sanction under S. 196A 2  of the Code, had not been obtained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies general rule to facts; object cheating per charges; rejects petitioner's procedural challenge.

holdings.text: The first contention that trial was illegal for lack of sanction is rejected.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from prior analysis of law and facts.

holdings.text: The evidence adduced establishes the guilt of the appellants; Sessions Judge and High Court correctly appreciated evidence; no justification for interference by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what is stated above, the first contention of the learned counsel for the appellants, has to be rejected. So far as the second contention is concerned... Both the learned Sessions Judge, as well as the High Court, have very elaborately gone into the evidence... and there is no justification for any interference, by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defers to lower courts' detailed evidence review; no error found.
